"The opposition is more interested in destabilizing the government and removing the president; than promoting the public wellness," he says. }}{{whose translation}} In CNT/MDA polls conducted in March 2015, only 10.8% of Brazilians approved of Rousseff's government and 59.7% wanted her impeached.{{cite news | title = Brazil poll: Rousseff popularity still falling, impeachment favored | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/07/21/us-brazil-rousseff-poll-idUSKCN0PV1K120150721 | accessdate = 21 July 2015 | agency = [[Reuters]] | date = 21 July 2015 }}{{cite web | url = http://cnt.mdapesquisa.com.br/img/relatoriosintese127.pdf | title = Pesquisa CNT/MDA - Relatório Síntese - Rodada 127 - 16 a 19 de março de 2015 | trans-title = Pools CNT/MDA - Syntesis Report - Round 127 - 16 to 19 March 2015 | accessdate = 25 December 2016 | author = CNT/MDA | date = March 2015 | language = pt }} By July 2015, the latter number had risen to 62.8%. Similar data were collected by the [[Datafolha|Datafolha Institute]] in April 2016, showing that 61% of Brazilians believed that Rousseff should be impeached.{{cite news | last1 = Romero | first1 = Simon | title = Effort to Impeach Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff Clears Congressional Panel | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/12/world/americas/brazil-panel-vote-dilma-rousseff-impeachment.html | accessdate = 14 April 2016 | work = [[The New York Times]] | date = 11 April 2016 }} ==Request for impeachment== A total of 37 requests for the impeachment of Rousseff had been presented to the Chamber of Deputies from 2012 till her actual impeachment. Of these 23 were archived and did not proceed. The remaining 14 proceeded, but only one was accepted by Cunha.{{cite web | url = http://www.gazetadopovo.com.br/blogs/certas-palavras/conheca-os-autores-dos-37-pedidos-de-impeachment-contra-dilma/ | title = Conheça os autores dos 37 pedidos de impeachment contra Dilma | trans-title = Know the authors of the 37 requests for impeachment against Dilma | publisher = Gazeta do Povo | date = 16 September 2015 | accessdate = 20 June 2016 | language = pt | dead-url = yes | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150923233850/http://www.gazetadopovo.com.br/blogs/certas-palavras/conheca-os-autores-dos-37-pedidos-de-impeachment-contra-dilma/ | archive-date = 23 September 2015 }} Submitted by former congressman and attorney [[Hélio Bicudo]] and attorneys {{Interlanguage link multi|Miguel Reale Júnior|pt}} and [[Janaína Paschoal]], it was based on allegations of omission concerning the Petrobras controversy, fiscal responsibility crimes, and budgetary mismanagement.{{cite web | url = https://www.ft.com/content/58401072-167d-11e6-b8d5-4c1fcdbe169f | title = What is Brazil's president Dilma Rousseff accused of? | work = Financial Times | author = Joe Leahy | date = 12 May 2016 }} ===Omission=== The illegal or suspicious transactions investigated by Operation Car Wash included the purchase of Pasadena Refinery by Petrobras, a deal that cost it R$792 million (US$362 million).{{cite web | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/brazil-petrobras-probe-idUSL1N13B0HV20151116 | title = Brazil prosecutors say bribes paid in Petrobras Texas refinery deal | agency = Reuters | author = Sergio Spagnuolo | date = 16 November 2015 | accessdate = 26 December 2016 }}{{cite web | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/08/09/business/international/effects-of-petrobras-scandal-leave-brazilians-lamenting-a-lost-dream.html | title = Petrobras Oil Scandal Leaves Brazilians Lamenting a Lost Dream | work = The New York Times | author = David Segal | date = 7 August 2015 | accessdate = 26 December 2016 }} Rousseff chaired the board of directors of Petrobras when the purchase was approved. She later said that a mistake had been made concerning a contractual clause and that "her decision was based on a technically and legally flawed summary" of the purchase document drawn up by {{Interlanguage link multi|Nestor Cerveró|pt}}, the financial director of [[Petrobras Distribuidora]] (the fuel distribution and trading subsidiary of Petrobras).{{cite web | url = http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/mar/21/scandal-involving-refinery-hits-brazils-petrobras/ | title = Scandal involving refinery hits Brazil's Petrobras | work = The Washington Times | author = Stan Lehman | date = 21 March 2014 | accessdate = 20 June 2016 }} Petrobras paid Astra Oil, a wholly owned subsidiary of Astro Oil Trading NV, $360 million for 50% of Pasadena Refining System.{{cite web | url = http://www.boe.ca.gov/meetings/pdf/hearingsummaries/B_Astra_Oil_Company_Inc_609368_Sum_121713.pdf | publisher = Board of Equalization, State of California | title = HEARING SUMMARY: CORPORATION FRANCHISE TAX APPEAL :Case No. 609368 | author = Louis A. Ambrose }} A year later, Astra exercised a [[put option]] that required Petrobras to buy out the other half, then won the arbitration case over the deal. In May 2015, Cerveró was convicted of money laundering and sentenced to five years in jail.{{cite web | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/petrobras-corruption/former-petrobras-executive-sentenced-to-five-years-jail-idUSL1N0YH1R620150526 | title = Former Petrobras executive sentenced to five years jail | agency = Reuters | date = 26 May 2015 }} The president called the allegations a kind of coup and merely an attempt to weaken Petrobras.{{citation needed|date=June 2017}} Emphasizing its expertise in the economy and energy sectors, the president stressed the company's financial health. She stepped down from the Petrobras board only in February 2015.Request for impeachment, pg 3, 4 and 5{{cite web | url = http://www.houstonchronicle.com/news/houston-texas/houston/article/Brazilian-scandal-centers-on-purchase-of-Pasadena-6618757.php | title = Brazilian scandal centers on purchase of Pasadena refinery | work = Houston Chronicle | author = Mihir Zaveri Susan Carroll and Ben Tavener | date = 13 November 2015 | accessdate = 20 June 2016 }} Some international companies were chosen to be encouraged and, thereafter participated in unrealistic bids to drain the state-owned company, giving back much of the value through seemingly licit donations.{{clarification needed|date=June 2017 |reason=Why "seemingly"?}} It was alleged that statements taken from the accused in Operation Car Wash suggested that Lula and Rousseff had known of the bribery scheme in Petrobras.Request for impeachment, pg 7 and 8{{cite web | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-35728124 | title = Why Brazil's Lula faces fresh corruption investigation | work = ''BBC News'' | date = 4 May 2016 | accessdate = 26 December 2016 }}{{cite web | url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/sep/14/brazil-petrobras-oil-kickback-scandal-luiz-inacio-lula-da-silva | title = Brazil's ex-president Lula charged with corruption in oil kickback scandal | work = The Guardian | agency = Reuters | date = 14 September 2016 | accessdate = 26 December 2016 }}{{cite web | url = http://politica.estadao.com.br/noticias/eleicoes,lula-e-dilma-sabiam-de-corrupcao-na-petrobras-diz-revista,1581917 | title = Lula e Dilma sabiam de corrupção na Petrobrás, diz revista | trans-title = Lula and Dilma knew of corruption in Petrobras, magazine says | work = [[O Estado de S. Paulo]] | date = 24 October 2014 | accessdate = 26 December 2016 | language = pt | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20171010122857/http://politica.estadao.com.br/noticias/eleicoes,lula-e-dilma-sabiam-de-corrupcao-na-petrobras-diz-revista,1581917 | archivedate = 10 October 2017 | deadurl = yes }} ===Fiscal responsibility crimes=== Rousseff issued six unnumbered decrees in 2014 and 2015 that allocated funds to social programs, allegedly for political purposes, without authorization from Congress. These totaled R$18.5 billion (US$6.9 billion) and were contracted in official financial institutions with neither the necessary legislative authorization, nor targets which complied with the Lei de Responsabilidade Fiscal (Fiscal Responsibility Law) and the {{Interlanguage link multi|Annual Budgetary Law|pt|3=Lei orçamentária anual}}. To obtain these additional credits, the target of 2014 was reduced by the end of 2014 by R$67 billion (US$25 billion) at the request of the president. Rousseff allegedly committed similar crimes of fiscal irresponsibility in 2015. She further issued such decrees in the years 2014 and 2015 to authorize the opening credit precisely to, purportedly, allow the provision of additional resources despite it being known that the primary ''superavit'' target in the budget forecast was not being fulfilled, and would not be fulfilled, hence disregarding the Annual Budgetary Law and the Federal Constitution.Request for impeachment, pg 13–21 ==="Fiscal pedaling"=== In 2011 and 2014, Rousseff's government is said to have held illegal credit operations, using funds from the state-owned banks [[Caixa Econômica Federal]] and [[Banco do Brasil]] to finance social programs without officially declaring loans from either of those banks, an example of fiscal pedaling. These transactions were reported in 2015 by the TCU and, according to the report, were undertaken in order to improve the government's chances of re-election.Request for impeachment, pg 22–38; pg.38: ''Com efeito, como evidenciado em sede de Representação Criminal encaminhada à Procuradoria Geral da República, ao fazer empréstimos proibidos e não os contabilizar, a Presidente da República poderia até, em tese, ser inclusa nas iras do artigo 299 do Código Penal, que tipifica a falsidade ideológica. A situação resta ainda mais grave, quando se constata que todo esse expediente fora intensificado durante o ano eleitoral, com o fim deliberado de iludir o eleitorado. Daí ser possível falar em verdadeiro estelionato eleitoral.''
(''In fact, as evidenced by a Criminal Representation sent to the Office of the Attorney General, by illegally taking loans and not accounting for them, the [actions of the] President could, in theory, be included under Article 299 of the Penal Code, which typifies identity fraud. The situation is even more serious if one observes that this procedure was intensified during election year, with the deliberate purpose of deceiving the electorate. Hence it is possible to talk about electoral fraud.'') See talk page for translation discussion. Caixa Econômica Federal and Banco do Brasil operated federal social programs under a government contract at this time. The government would pass the funds necessary to finance the programs through the {{Interlanguage link multi|Secretariat of the National Treasury|pt|3=Secretaria do Tesouro Nacional}} every month. They were obliged to transfer the equivalent values for the equalization of interest rates, expenditures and legal transfers covered under the contract. But the government had not made these reimbursements, and the contracted banks instead funded the programs using their own capital, capital that the government was obliged to reimburse them for, although no loans had been officially filed. The Fiscal Responsibility Law (Article 36) prohibits members of the federal government who control state financial institutions from borrowing from those institutions that they control. The total balance of these liabilities by the end of August 2014 was R$1.74 billion (US$740 million). Of the total R$7.8 billion (US$2.9 billion) spent on subsidies in these programs between 2009 and 2014, only R$1.6 billion (US$590 million) was transferred by the Government.Request for impeachment, pg 25–27 At the end of 2014, Rousseff sent the Congress [[Bill (law)|PLN]] 362014, to change the {{Interlanguage link multi|Budgetary Directives Law|pt|3=Lei de diretrizes orçamentárias}} in order to modify the rules of the primary ''superavit'' (surplus), and hence showing her knowledge of the fiscal pedaling by taking steps to normalize the accounts.Request for impeachment, pg 45 == Process in After it passed out of committee, the full lower house also voted in favor of impeachment, 367 for and 137 against, with 342 necessary for it to pass (7 abstaining, 2 absent). {{cite web | url = http://www2.camara.leg.br/camaranoticias/noticias/POLITICA/507325-CAMARA-AUTORIZA-INSTAURACAO-DE-PROCESSO-DE-IMPEACHMENT-DE-DILMA-COM-367-VOTOS-A-FAVOR-E-137-CONTRA.html | title = Câmara autoriza committee, 303 of the 513 members of the lower house were facing criminal charges or investigation at the time of the vote. Cunha then referred the matter to the Senate which eventually, after a session of more than twenty hours on 12 May, resolved to suspend Rousseff's presidential powers and duties for up to 180 days, a motion which passed 55{{ndash}}22. During the judicial process leading up to the Senate vote on impeachment, then Vice President Michel Temer served as acting president.{{cite news | title = Brazil's Dilma Rousseff to face impeachment trial | url = https://www.bbc.com/news/world-latin-america-36273916 | accessdate = 12 May 2016 | date = 12 May 2016 | publisher = [[BBC News]] }} But before that, on 5 May 2016, Teori Zavascki, judge of the [[Supreme Federal Court (Brazil)|Supreme Federal Court]] ruled that Cunha must step down as president of the Chamber, because he faced a corruption trial. The decision was later endorsed by all eleven judges of the Court but nevertheless did not affect the process of impeachment.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/06/world/americas/cunha-rousseff-brazil-impeachment.html?rref=collection%2Ftimestopic%2FRousseff%2C%20Dilma&action=click&contentCollection=timestopics®ion=stream&module=stream_unit&version=latest&contentPlacement=2&pgtype=collection | title = Brazilian Lawmaker Behind Rousseff Impeachment Is Told to Step Down | work = The New York Times | author = Simon Romero | date = 5 May 2016 | accessdate = 6 May 2016 }} On 12 September 2016, Cunha was finally ousted from the Chamber with his political rights suspended under accusation of lying in testimony to the committee investigating Operation Car Wash allegations, the culmination of an internal investigation that had lasted eleven months.{{cite web | url = http://agenciabrasil.ebc.com.br/en/politica/noticia/2016-09/brazil-lower-house-ousts-suspended-deputy-eduardo-cunha | title = Brazil lower house ousts suspended deputy Eduardo Cunha | publisher = Agência Brasil | author = Luciano Nascimento | date = 13 September 2016 | accessdate = 26 December 2016 }} On 19 October 2016, Cunha was arrested on charges of corruption and bribery related to a Petrobras [[drillship]] purchase. {{cite web | url = http://agenciabrasil.ebc.com.br/en/politica/noticia/2016-10/brazil-former-lower-house-speaker-arrested | title = Brazil: former lower house speaker arrested | publisher = Agência Brasil | author = Michèlle Canes | date = 19 October 2016 | accessdate = 26 December 2016 }} {|class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" style="font-size:100%;
